title: Boy who suffered severe asthma attack dies after being removed from life support despite court fight
text:
A teenager who suffered a severe asthma attack has died after being removed from his life support machine despite his family battling to keep him on it.

Bobby Reyes, 14, was taken off the breathing machine after Michigan Medicine performed a second test on Tuesday morning that found had no detectable brain or brain stem function.

The hospital said the family gathered in his room when they discontinued ventilation, holding a vigil for him.

It followed a court battle where Reyes' family fought for three weeks to keep doctors at C.S. Mott Children's Hospital in Michigan from performing a second brain scan.

The legal struggle culminated when a circuit court judge lifted the stay in place Tuesday saying he did not have jurisdiction as the paperwork need to be filed in a state court.

The hospital added in a statement obtained by the DailyMail.com, 'Further testing — including an electroencephalogram (EEG) and a cerebral blood flow study — detected no electrical activity and no blood flow to Bobby’s brain.'

The sad saga of 14-year-old Bobby Reyes ended Tuesday when the hospital, by state law, removed the brain dead teenager from life support

Happier times for a 14-year-old Michigan boy who died after a severe asthma attack left him brain dead

'By law in Michigan, an individual is dead who has sustained either irreversible cessation of circulatory and respiratory functions or irreversible cessation of all function of the entire brain, including the brain stem,' the statement said.

The hospital also wrote that to continue medical interventions was 'inappropriate' after Reyes was officially declared brain dead and it 'violates the professional integrity of Michigan Medicine's clinicians.'

The family of Bobby Reyes holds a bedside vigil after a judge ruled a second brain test can be performed, which confirmed he was brain dead

The family of Bobby Reyes didn't get help from the courts or the hospital to save the brain dead boy

According to the hospital, his caregivers worked hard with the family to arrange for a transfer to another facility. However. all of the facilities, more than 20, refused to extend his care.

“It was so quick,” Reyes' mother Sarah Jones told WXYZ.

Late last month the boy experienced a bad asthma attack that even his inhaler couldn't help.

By the time she called 9-1-1, Reyes stopped breathing, despite never having a serious asthma episode.

He was airlifted to the hospital and doctors determined he was brain dead. A first test was done Sept. 24. But state law requires a second test to confirm the diagnosis.

'Our team at Michigan Medicine sympathizes with the Reyes family and is committed to providing support in this difficult time.'
description: Michigan teenager suffered a severe asthma attack leaving him brain dead. C.S. Mott Children's Hospital said any medical intervention after being declared brain dead would be 'inappropriate'
